title: Crowdsourcing idea is interesting but synthetic data is not
review:
Review of "Data Interpretation and Reasoning Over Scientific Plots"

Paper summary:

The paper is concerned with algorithms that can interpret data shown
in scientific plots. The algorithm is given a plot and a question, and
is required to predict an answer. The main contribution of this paper
is a new (synthetic) data set which is much larger than previous data
sets. It is claimed that the proposed DIP data set is "more realistic"
than previous data sets. (in terms of variable names, values,
questions) The paper also proposes a baseline model/pipeline for these
data. 

The paper proposes the (new?) idea of using crowdsourced workers to
create natural language questions. 3500 plots were each shown to 5
different works, creating a total of 17,500 questions. After that, the
authors manually clustered the questions into 5 classes and 74
templates, from which they generated the DIP data set. It contains
273,821 plots (presumably with

The model (pipeline) consists of four sub-tasks:
- visual element detection, which consists of predicting bounding boxes for axis labels, tick marks, legends, etc. A Single Shot Multibox Detector model is trained for this task.
- optical character recognition is performed using a pre-trained OCR model.
- Semi-structured information extraction is performed using is done using a "use the closest" heuristic.
- table question answering using a previous method.

Detailed comments:

The main strong point of the paper is the manually collected
crowdsource data. The paper is also quite clear and easy to read and
understand.

However there are too many weak points to merit publication.

It is clear that the model is NOT a significant contribution to the
machine learning literature, as it simply uses previous work.

It is not clear that the data set is a significant contribution to the machine
learning literature. Machine learning has made progress in recent
years because of the emphasis on analyzing real (not synthetic)
benchmark data sets, in which the pattern is unknown. If this kind of
synthetic data is interesting in another field of research, maybe this
paper could be resubmitted elsewhere in the current form?

Otherwise, publishing the full data that were actually collected from
real people (not synthetically generated) is a productive research
direction for the machine learning community. Would that be possible?

If you really want to train on synthetic data, then the interesting
question is, can you train on your synthetic data and then get good
results on the real data (test-hard) from crowdsourced workers? This
question is not answered in the paper. "However, we do not use the
test-hard split for our experiments." why not?

Why does the test-hard data set only have 1000 observations? Why not
use the entire set of 17,500 that you gathered?

A weak point is that the paper offers no empirical comparison with
previous models, and simply claims that they are not good enough. "it
is infeasible to use any of the existing VQA models on our dataset as
they largely treat VQA as a multi-class classification problem where
the task is to select the right answer from a fixed vocabulary"

Figures are not publication quality. In particular the text in figures
1c, 2 is too small to read.

Tables are not publication quality. Table 1 has a confusing comma on
the first(train) line -- is there a missing number? Tables 2-5 need
Standard deviations or confidence intervals. You should use K-fold
cross validation instead of a fixed train/validation/test split. In
practice you can do that by publishing a file with a suggested Fold ID
(say from 1 to 5) for each observation.

"The data contains positive integers, floating point values,
percentages and values on a linear scale." -- what is a value on a
linear scale?
